|Title=Know how to prescribe emergency samples prior to antibiotic therapy
|Description=Know how to prescribe blood cultures prior to emergency antibiotic therapy
|Section=Additional tests
|Contributors=David Lebeaux
|Order=8}}
Microbiological tests must be taken before the start of antibiotic therapy (including the [[Positive blood culture SD-190|haemocultures]], see below).

The exceptions to this rule are :

- Purpura fulminans

- Patients presenting with septic shock or bacterial meningitis whose microbiological sampling would delay the start of antibiotic therapy by more than one hour.

properties.question: Before initiating antibiotic therapy for bacteremia/fungemia, which of the following is the correct protocol for microbiological testing?
properties.option_a: Perform microbiological tests after starting antibiotic therapy to confirm the presence of bacteria.
properties.option_b: Obtain microbiological samples, including haemocultures, before starting antibiotic therapy, except in cases of septic shock or bacterial meningitis where delays are acceptable.
properties.option_c: Only perform microbiological tests in cases of suspected fungemia, regardless of the timing of antibiotic therapy.
properties.option_d: Avoid microbiological tests as they may interfere with the effectiveness of antibiotic therapy.
